title: 107_s930
content:
The "Grand Canyon Capital Improvements Act of 2001" includes sections on short title, definitions, fundraising organization, memorandum of agreement, park surcharge, use of bond proceeds, report, and regulations. SEC. 2. DEFINITIONS.

Fundraising organization - entity authorized under section 3(a).
Memorandum of agreement - agreement entered into by Secretary under section 3(a) with terms specified in section 4.
Park - Grand Canyon National Park.
Secretary - Secretary of the Interior. The Secretary may enter into a memorandum of agreement with an entity to act as an authorized fundraising organization for the benefit of the Park. The fundraising organization shall issue taxable bonds in return for the surcharge collected for the Park. It must comply with professional standards and be subject to an audit by the Secretary. The United States shall not be liable for the bonds. The fundraising organization must undergo an audit by the Secretary. The United States is not responsible for the security of any bonds issued by the organization. SEC. 4. MEMORANDUM OF AGREEMENT. The fundraising organization must enter a memorandum of agreement detailing the bond issue amount, bond maturity not exceeding 20 years, per capita amount for bond repayment and administration costs, reserve requirements, funded projects at the Park, and procedures for agreement modifications. The fundraising organization must enter a memorandum of agreement detailing the bond issue amount, maturity not exceeding 20 years, per capita amount for repayment and administration costs, reserve requirements, funded projects at the Park, and procedures for modifications with consent of both parties based on changes in circumstances. SEC. 5. PARK SURCHARGE OR SET-ASIDE. The Secretary may authorize the Superintendent of the Park to charge a surcharge of up to $2 per individual in addition to entrance fees collected under specific acts. The Secretary may authorize a surcharge of up to $2 per individual under specific acts such as the Land and Water Conservation Fund Act of 1965, the recreational fee demonstration program, or the national park passport program. The total amount charged may not exceed $2 for each individual charged an entrance fee. The Secretary may authorize a surcharge of up to $2 per individual under specific acts for entrance fees. The surcharge must be used to amortize bond issues, cover administration costs, and maintain a reserve as determined by the bond underwriter. SEC. 6. USE OF BOND PROCEEDS. Bond proceeds under this Act can be used for projects in the Park, subject to certain limitations and prohibitions on administrative use. The bond proceeds can be used for Park projects, with restrictions on administrative expenses. No bond proceeds can be used for administrative expenses except for interest. Interest earned can be used for reserve requirements and reasonable administrative expenses related to bond management and sale. The Secretary must submit a report to Congress on the bond program within 2 years of regulations being issued. The report will review the program at the Park and provide recommendations on establishing a bond program at all National Park units. The Secretary, in consultation with the Secretary of Treasury, will promulgate regulations to implement the Act.
